p.s: how are you?
I am fine, thanks.
You wrote me about your high school thinking about banning The Hate U Give from the curriculums and the school libraries.
The arguments are the sexual references, the offensive too vulgar language, the promotion of drug abuse and the showing of the police in a negative light.
A few letters ago, I told you that I have read the novel in class and that it is even recommended reading in Germany.
Now I am going to tell you why The Hate U Give should be compulsory reading not only in the US, but also worldwide.
During my research on the internet I found an interesting article of Zeit Online named Schwarze in der USA: Der Rassismus ist messbar" by Alexandra Endres, published on 25.08.2014.
She says that racism exists these days in America although president Lyndon B. Jonson put an end to the discrimination of coloured people with the Civil Rights Act 50 years ago.
I do not know if you heard about the shooting of the 18-year-old African-American Michael Brown tow weeks before Alexandra Endres' article got published?
This event clarifies that apartheid does exist in the US.

Besides statistics prove the unequal treatytreatment of coloured people in America, e.g. that stop-and-frisk is more strictly used at African Americans than whites or that coloured men have more risk of getting a stint in prison.
Only a few African Americans leave school with a good qualification or get a higher academic qualification.
More coloured people than whites have no job - even if they got a high qualification.
Do you know that?
The same statistics prove that there is one quarter of African Americans living in poverty and only less than a tenth of whites.
The Hate U Give raises the differences by the sixteen-year-old coloured girl Starr living at a poor, balck environment, but going to a primarily white high school.

In my opinion The Hate U Give should be compulsory reading worlwide, because her point of view is very authentic as a first personfirst-person narrator and the reader experiences her events at her home at Garden Height as well as the private school at one of the suburbs.
The point of view on the situation in the US told by an African American should be proper education.
I hope I could help you.
Greetings to your family.
